key_points: Jury selection for Kyle Rittenhouse's trial and the trial for the men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery occurred simultaneously.
Rittenhouse is charged with killing two people and wounding another during a Kenosha protest; he claims self-defense.
Rittenhouse pleaded not guilty to charges, including homicide and possession of a firearm by a minor.
Video evidence plays a significant role in both the Rittenhouse and Arbery trials.
The Arbery case involves three men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery, who they pursued while he was jogging.
Travis McMichael, one of the defendants in the Arbery case, also plans to claim self-defense.
Both cases have drawn national attention, partly due to the contentious nature and the evidence involved.
Legal experts and attorneys highlight the complexities that video evidence brings to each case.
The former Kenosha city alderman called for "patriots" to defend Kenosha, which Rittenhouse responded to.
The Arbery and Rittenhouse cases have sparked discussions about race, self-defense laws, and gun rights.
spokespersons: Chris Slobogin (Law Professor at Vanderbilt University, Director of the Criminal Justice Program)
